segments.text: Okay, this is Ron Shorin at the American Astronaut Society meeting in Berkeley, California on June 9, 1993.
I'm going to interview Don Wells.
So, Don, for the record, would you give us your full name?
My name is Donald C. Wells.
That's how I usually use my name professionally.
I'm 51 years old.
I was born in 1941.
Where?
In Texas.
I'm a native Texan from Beaumont, Texas.
I entered graduate school in astronomy.
Let's just go back.
I wanted to ask you, where you got first interested in astronomy?
Oh, now there's an interesting question.
Actually, I don't know.
I grew up in the 50s reading Heinlein and other science fiction writers.
was really fascinated by space and that sort of thing.
But actually, I think the interest goes deeper.
And I was always after kind of ultimate things and the limits.
And in fact, the result of that is in astronomy, I went toward cosmology.
So for me, I viewed planets as one little step along the way, and I was really after cosmology.
That was how I originally thought.
And so I gravitated in that direction.
But actually, as a young person, I didn't know anything about how people became astronomers.
And so as I was in high school and I studied physics, then I knew about physics.
I also grew up in a heavy industry area.
And so engineers were the highly honored people in that environment.
Intellectuals were unknown.
And so the highest goal was to be an engineer.
And the net effect of that was when I went off to university education, I thought the object of the game was to be an engineer.
Where did you do your undergraduate work?
I went to Rice.
And I started in EE.
And this would have been 1960.
I graduated from high school in 1960.
And so I originally started in double E. And in a freshman physics course, I became terrifically fascinated with Newtonian physics and all the basic physics stuff.
And that just resonated real deeply.
And so I switched to physics.
And however, I have all through my life thought and acted a lot like an engineer in many ways.
So I'm a kind of hybrid person in between engineering and physics.
But my real love is physics in the end.
When you graduated, where did you go to grad school?
I graduated in 1964.
I applied to two places for grad school.
I should have applied for more.
I must say that as a physics major, as I approached my senior year, I actually came to the realization that I didn't really want to do what most physicists did.
And I was groping around, and I had an astrophysics course in about my senior year, junior year, senior year.
And I didn't actually know anything about how to be an astronomer.

And that's an interesting commentary, that I was a physics student in the 60s, early 60s, and there was essentially at that time almost no information available to me about how to become an astronomer.
One of my professors, he was a department chairman at the time, I asked him, and he had a fellow grad student when he was in school who had become an astronomer.
And so he had some knowledge of what you did to be an astronomer.
And he gave me a few hints.
And with that, I was off and running.
I right away discovered where the grad schools were and applied.
Texas offered me money.
The other place I applied didn't offer me money, although it was Wisconsin, as it happens.
In retrospect, had I gone to Wisconsin, I almost certainly would have been in the OAO program.
They would have paid me in the end, and I would have wound up doing probably ultraviolet astronomy, and who knows?
I'd have gone into the space side of astronomy more directly.
Instead, I went to Texas and went into the ground-based side of astronomy.
So it's one of those little things, you know, flip of the coin, you'd go one way or the other.
When I went to Texas, one of my very first courses was from Gerard de Vaucouleur.
And it was on extragalactic astronomy.
And I just gravitated right to that.
And Gerard had a planetary side as well.
And he was, even then, at that time, doing, for example, a map of Mars, as I recall.
He had an artist busy drawing maps of visual observations of Mars at that time.
Anyway, you were starting to ask a question.
What did you do your thesis on?
Oh, you mean in grad school?
Yeah.
Actually, I did two theses, or tried two different things.
I started on a thesis on blue galaxies as Mercurian-type galaxies with Dan Weidman, who was a young professor then at
I guess he was an assistant professor in the Department of Texas.
And he decided right in the midst of that to take a position at Penn State.
So he got a tenure track offer at Penn State.
And off he goes to Penn State.
And I decided not to follow him.
I decided to stay at Texas.
At that point, I gave up on the original thesis.
It wasn't working out too well anyway.
The universe wasn't cooperating.
And so Gerard offered me a suggestion, and I went with Gerard, and I did spectrophotometry of galaxies to get K corrections, and that was cosmology.
I was directly a part of observational cosmology, so I was really an observational cosmology person.
And I wound up doing a postdoc in that,
But my other big love was computing.
So all through the midst of all this, I had a really heavy interest in computing.
Totally self-taught, but at a very high level.
And so ultimately, my whole career has been divided between science and computing.
And computing is mostly one over the years.
I remember you were in the bowels of the 107-inch when that thing was getting going.
What did you do on that project?
I was a co-designer, builder, programmer,
of the control software for the 107-inch, pointing the machine and moving it around, get it on targets, doing pointing calculations, that sort of thing.
I had a partner who was a long-time friend of mine named Mike McCants.
He and I did that project.
an early computer-controlled telescope in optical astronomy.
In Harlan's tapes and transcripts, Harlan Smith, he states that Westinghouse completely fouled up the control system and people had to basically start from scratch.
He may be speaking of things like the servos and that sort of thing.
And I seem to recall that he had an engineer who did build a digital servo system for the telescope, and that that was a somewhat innovative thing in that time.
Now, that's the actual servo controls.

We were at a higher level, so if you wanted to observe Venus, we built a control system where you could say, point Venus, and it would work out an ephemeris, calculate the current apparent position, apply all the corrections for the telescope's pointing errors, and command the servo system to move the machine to that position and set the tracking rates so that it would track the moving target.
So we could work out all those kind of higher-level calculations.
That's what I mean by the control system.
But an engineer who was responsible for the servos, for motor control, would think that it was the digital servo loops.
That may be what Harlan was referring to.
I don't think our part of the project was something that Westinghouse would have ever been responsible for.
It was always going to be our job.
So once the mechanical end of the telescope was done, then you people took over.
Yeah.
Yes.
It was a pure software effort.
Although we were concerned about the pointing errors, the mechanical errors of the machine, which are inevitable, and calibrating those and accounting for them.
The reason I'm interested in this is, of course, that that was funded with NASA money.
Yes.
Through planetary astronomy.
Right.
One of the most innovative things we did in that software, which is almost unmatched, I think, elsewhere, was that
we had an ability to point at targets on the moon.
There's practically no other telescope control system that ever did.
I've never actually heard of one that did that.
But because of the Lunar Laser Ranging Program, it was necessary to hit targets at points on the moon, accounting for current lunar ephemeris.
Where is the moon, and what is its orientation, and where are we?
where are the features, or where is the reflection?
Yeah, right.
So we had xi, eta coordinates in the coordinate system of the moon.
So you could pick out a crater on the moon, and you'd look up at xi, eta coordinates, and you could say, point moon xi, eta, you know, xi this, eta that.
So you'd say where on the moon you wanted to go, and we had named features, and we had a table.
I think we had named features for some of the objects on the moon, and you had a table of their coordinates, so you could say, point at them by name on the moon, you know, a crater by name.
And that was really pretty exotic to do a calculation of where the objects would be in apparent coordinates and also their tracking rates.
And then the next part of the story is that many of the targets you wanted to fire at were on the dark side of the moon, so you couldn't even see them.
And you had unknown pointing errors because in spite of all our efforts to calibrate the machine, there's uncalibratable errors.
So what you do is you offset from a visible source to the invisible source.
And so, in fact, what we would do is point at a bright object, an object on the bright side, the illuminated side, zero the crosshairs on it.
tell the computer, now note the zero error, now go to this other guy that's over here in the dark, in the shadow, and that's where they were going to fire the laser.
And we could do all this in the summer of 1969 at Apollo 11.
As I recall at that time, there were a number of other observatories that were trying to do the same thing, and they did not have this kind of control system, and eventually some of them got returns.

um laser returns but as i recall they kind of once they got their picture in the paper they kind of gave up because it was just too hard to do without this control system that you had maybe it was maybe it was i i'm on i i didn't know much about that because we were just support personnel for the activity we thought my partner and i mike mckenzie and i thought it was a wonderful fascinating control and computing problem
And we were in uncharted territory, and we loved it because we knew we could do it.
We believed it was all going to work, and it did, and it was all a fascinating problem for us.
But we ourselves weren't all that interested in planetary work.
We viewed the whole thing as an interesting logical problem, mathematical and physical problem to stretch our minds on.
On the other hand, it would have been very difficult to do routine lunar ranging work or routine Venus stuff without this control system.
Did anybody, the people who used the stuff you made, did they ever give you any credit in print?
I do not know.
I do not know.
Because it's my theory that people like you and Bob Toll and John Geary and CFA and everybody like that do all this stuff without which, quote, observers can't observe.
And you're invisible people as far as that works out.
There's a lot of truth to this.
Like, that lunar laser ranging data is mostly going to appear in a table in some A.J.
or some other journal, probably under the author of Daryl Mulholland,
somebody like that.
And it's going to appear as a set of precision results and model fits and that sort of thing.
And that's the ultimate result of it.
And along the way, you know, he just announces this came from the 107 inch and probably doesn't say much more than that.
And I mean, how can I fault him?
This has been standard practice forever.
Do you get to publish some of this stuff in like the Journal for Computer Control of Telescopes or whatever?
Not in that era.
Nowadays, well, in the last decade or so, there is more of a mechanism.
First, for example, in the AAS, there's a thing called the Working Group for Astronomical Software, which was first proposed by Ivan King when he was president of the society in 1980.
And I was the first chairman of that working group.
For about five years, I was chairman of it.
And one of the goals of that group was to provide a forum where astronomical software people could get together and talk and get some kind of recognition.
And over the years, the WGAS has promoted, particularly under Bob Hennish, who's the current chairman,
promoted some of this kind of activity of journal recognition, paper publication.
So in this AAS meeting on Monday, there were poster paper sessions that were WGAS related, and there was a paper session, oral paper session on Monday morning that was WGAS related.
And in it, software people in astronomy got to talk about what they were doing.
But this is a continuing problem.
We haven't really solved it.

Also, it's true that under this era of the last decade with Bob Hanisch, and not just WGS, but equivalent groups in Europe, for example, have also recognized the problem, and they've pestered the journals, the publication committees, and there's been a broadening of the guidelines of what's publishable, what is considered appropriate for our journals.
And so in principle, the policies in print now say that instrumentation papers of this kind, including software things, not just optical instruments.
Somebody could always publish a paper on a new spectrometer.
but software sort of arose in the more recent period and they weren't quite sure how we fit into the picture.
Well, now the policies say that these things are publishable.
And so it's not finished.
The solution's not completely in hand, but there's a lot of improvement.
This situation really never arose in radio astronomy because if you had some new deal, you would publish it in the proceedings of the IRE.
The software people...
No, I'm not so sure I agree.
The hardware people, yes.
They had a long tradition on the hardware side.
So if they built a new receiver, they could certainly publish it in an engineering journal.
There's comparatively little papers on the software side of systems.
And that's somewhat true even today, that there's still not a full recognition for software as a form of instrumentation.
That's really the issue that you're coming to.
And in fact, that's the way I view it.
I view software as a form of instrumentation
And in the last two decades, it's become sine qua non, just like all the other instrumentation.
And in fact, this is generally agreed to and understood.
But however, the tradition of publishing papers around it is not as fully developed as it ought to be.
The software is kind of amorphous.
It's mind stuff, ultimate mind stuff.
It's not tangible objects.
Tangible objects are easy to write about.
Amorphous mind stuff is slippery.
You can't pin it down exactly.
Even with hardware, as you know, Bob Tull was so busy building equipment for people like me to use.
among others, that he was refused tenure because he didn't write enough papers about the sky.
And that's with hard work, OK, which was a better position than software.
And I'll say one thing for Harlan that he realized that without Bob Tall, the conservatory would be in some trouble.
I was a member of the first generation that had this problem on the software side.
I made a decision.
While I was in grad school, actually, I decided that the main thing that I could do for science was to specialize in information handling.
In that era, that was a pretty...
foolhardy decision to make, although it was a straight calculation on my part of what the future was going to bring.
The calculation was dead accurate.
I was right on the mark.
I knew what was going to happen.
All my predictions were basically correct.
However, I also knew that meant that I wasn't tenure-tracked.
And I understood that consequence of the calculation, too.

And although I made a half-hearted attempt to go for tenure, kind of, to play the academic game, I wasn't really capable of being simultaneously a bona fide research scientist and also a software instrumentation person.
It was just too much.
I wasn't good enough.
Do you think this is a hangover from the days of, like, Galileo and Herschel, when an astronomer did everything?
He built his telescope, he observed, he did this, did that.
Back when it was easier to do that, of course.
I agree with you that you can't do it these days.
OK.
It's too hard.
So I ultimately gave up on, I gave up mentally on the idea of going for tenure.
I acknowledged that I was never going to get it.
I actually had no idea how I was going to survive because
When I entered graduate school, there was no mechanism of employment in astronomy that could find a way for you to have a position, a permanent position, that wasn't tenure track.
You alluded to Bob.
He had exactly the same problem.
And yet, he became a research associate and was put on the observatory payroll and, as a practical matter, had tenure, although officially he didn't.
Personally, one result of all this is that I'm kind of scornful of the notion of academic tenure and think that oftentimes it's given to people who then sit around for another 20 years.
Whereas folk like Bob and me sort of have to continually re-justify our existence.
When one project ends, there's probably another one coming, and we'll have to once again prove ourselves.
And it's a little bit of a strain.
One gets tired of it after a while.
But on the other hand, there's also a sense of fairness about it.
The notion of academic tenure, I'm not all that fond of the notion.
I think the arguments for it are a little self-serving.
But anyway, people like Bob Toll on the instrumentation side and me on the software instrumentation side did have a problem with how...
The fundamental way of saying the problem was there weren't job titles for us.
If you just looked in the roster of job titles that the personnel office had, there wasn't any box to put us into.
And this was recognized by the observatories.
It was understood that in this era of high-tech systems, large-scale systems that were complex, involved a lot of technologies, and there was rapid evolution of the technologies,
it was understood that you were going to have to have a cadre of technical people who were in the structure more or less permanently, and that you just simply weren't going to operate without them.
And so the administrators came to the conclusion they had to create some new job titles, and they did.
Bob, I think, was always a research associate, but for software people like me, there weren't any job titles.
Actually, big institutions really did have the problem even for the hardware guys.

There were people like me who were bona fide astronomers, who did read the table of contents of the AppJ as it came on the shelf every month, who understood the physics and the astronomy and actually did care about it a lot.
but who were, in fact, systems people.
And observatories had to make decisions about that.
And in the US, I was one of the first people to get a new job title.
It was Support Scientist was the name given for it.
And what institution?
This was at Kitt Peak National Observatory.
When did you leave Texas?
I graduated from Texas in September of 72.
That was when I had my oral exam.
And I was at Texas eight years.
I was in grad school eight years.
That was a long, long time.
One reason was an aborted dissertation that only started and didn't go too far.
The second reason was that throughout the eight years, I worked half time.
In fact, I built a telescope control system, which is not the sort of thing you'd expect a grad student to do.
I built half a dozen or more instrument control systems.
It may have been eight or ten of them.
I did a whole series of projects.
I had substantial published papers.
I'd done almost every kind of computing, data reduction, instrument control, telescope control.
I'd even done astrophysics calculations, stark broadening functions with a kind of theoretical approach.
paper where I was the computing person.

So I'd done all kinds of computing, and I'd been employed as a computing person for eight years throughout the time I was in grad school, which is a large part of the reason why I was in grad school a very long time.
So I graduated in 72, September of 72, and I went to Kitt Peak as a postdoc, and
I was doing cosmology observations, but they were at that time bringing the Mayall 4 meter online, and they actually didn't have very many people with skills like mine.
One of the reasons they'd hired me was they wanted to get my kind of skills because they knew they needed them.
And so I just gravitated into the Mayall 4 meter.
I was the software designer on the control system for the Mayall 4 meter, the first original control system.
So you got your new title, what, after a year?
Yeah, they acknowledged that they had to invent a new title.
So I became a support scientist, and I spent nine years at Kitt Peak.
I was a software designer, built image processing systems, instrument control systems, data reduction software.
I did a little bit of just about everything.
And there were two other people.
There was an infrared instrumentation person who got the title at the same time.
Who was that?
Joyce, Dick Joyce.

He's still an infrared instrument person, but he was also a person who was plenty competent and knowledgeable in astronomy, but apparently was never going to make it in tenure track, and yet you just couldn't run.
You couldn't run an observatory without him.
You needed his people, so they acknowledged this.
The third person, I think, was Ingemar Furinlid, who's now, I believe, in Georgia.
I believe he was the third one at the time.
I remember there were three of us, and he was an optical spectroscopy person, high-resolution spectroscopy person, so he was doing photography and spectrographs and that sort of thing.
Once again, a specialist in instrument management.
Now, big observatories like NOAO, Kitpeak NOAO, or NREO, are full of people with this title.
And at NREO, the...
In fact, NREO has now largely obliterated the distinctions in the job titles.
They still have a notion of tenure, but my title is now associate scientist and it's logically equivalent to associate professor, but I'm not a tenured, not strictly speaking, tenured.
When did you leave Kitt Peak and why?
I left in 1981.
Well, there was a lot of administrative turbulence at Kitt Peak in those years.
And I was in a, well, people like me who are in a support role wind up getting assigned to technical divisions who do not necessarily have sympathy for the fact that we are also scientists.
And as a scientist, I'm trained as an independent researcher, and I'm trained to be an independent thinker.
And I'm just naturally a rather ornery and intellectually independent person.
That's the nature of it.
Only people like us ever get to the top and get a PhD.
So there's a terrific selection effect there.

necessarily a good person to be told what to do and then to be put into a technical division and put under technical management if that technical management isn't astute enough to realize what's going on you can get problems created so
Anyway, there was turbulence in the computing division at that time, a lot of change of personnel, a lot of policy problems.
There was generally a lot of turbulence at Kitt Peak in that era.
Jeff Burbage was director.
There was a lot of controversy around.
And anyway, they appointed somebody over me who insulted me on the day he was appointed.
so I decided I would leave.
I'd about had enough.

I'd been there nine years anyway, and I was getting a little tired of what I'd been doing, and prospects didn't look too good with a lot of controversy going on, so I called up one of my friends and 60 days later moved to NREO.
So I've
I've continued doing more or less the same thing, software systems.
And I generally define myself as being interested in information handling in astronomy, observational astronomy research.
So I'm interested in the support of observational astronomy research.
And information for me is everything from photons in the sky to ink on a journal page.
I originally was mostly interested in things like cosmology, but as the years have gone by, my view of the universe has broadened a lot, and I'm now totally panchromatic in my view.
and my old disdain for things like planets is all gone now.
And so I view all of astronomy as one big thing that's all valuable.
All kinds of planetary astronomers spun.
Planetary, stellar, extra-galactic astronomers, they all sponge off of you, right?
Well, I guess.
I'm just saying that I myself no longer have the prejudices I had as a young fellow.
That's what I was going to ask you.
Back when you were in grad school, did you notice...
a sneering disdain on the part of real astronomers for Planetary One?
Yeah.
There's no question it existed.
And I've effectively confessed to it, to being a part of it, although I certainly earned money off of planetary astronomy in those days.
It's a fact that
that the NASA money had to fund planetary astronomy and had to deliberately subsidize it on ground-based astronomy in particular as an adjunct to the space program.
I'm sure that was necessary.
And even today, I suppose a lot of the funding of planetary work is strictly NASA money, even now.
Yeah.
And what I've also said to you, though, is that I personally, I can't speak for anybody else, but I personally
no longer have this prejudice.
But that's something that came to me over the years.
I was also strictly an optical person, and I thought only cosmology mattered.
and I have a much broader view of science now.

It's interesting that you would have that early view being at McDonald, being at the University of Texas at McDonald, which was one of the few places, actually the only place with a really large telescope or telescopes that were the major portion of the time to planetary observance.
Sure.
It is a little unusual.
I could easily have gone into planetary work.
When I was nearing my completion of my degree, I seriously considered
going to JPL.
In effect, I got an invitation to go to JPL.
In fact, they really wanted me to go, not bother to finish my degree.
They want you to work on radars or what?
Well, the person who was making the effort was Reinhold Beer, who had brought his big Fourier transform spectrometer to the 107-inch,
And I had been around, and we had talked a lot, and he had seen me, and so he essentially attempted to recruit a computing person for JPL.
And I was well aware of what he was doing, and I was well aware that I'd be entering the space program, planetary work, and all that.
And I did seriously consider it.
I even traveled to JPL, thought about it a lot, but decided to finish my degree under de Vaucouleur.
And I did.
And so that was, once again, the fork in the road.
One could have decided, and there was a case where the planetary money almost captured me.
NASA money almost captured me.
Do you find radio astronomers different to work with than optical astronomers?
That's a good question, Ron.
One can give several kinds of answers.
Single-dish radio astronomers are psychologically pretty similar to optical astronomers, and they're somewhat ornery and competitive, and they have some problems in cooperating.
whereas large-scale interferometric radio astronomy tends to be more of a community activity, and there is a tendency to be somewhat more cooperative, and that's especially true in VOBI.
The VOBI guys are basically very easy to get along with, because if they're not, they got selected out of the field, since VOBI could only operate on a cooperative basis.
I'm very aware of this.
I just spent five years working with BLBI people.
That's a very long baseline interferometry.
Exactly.
Which NASA is now putting a lot of money into with the Radio Astron VSOP program, which is coming out of JPL.
And I'm very impressed with how they get along with each other.
Whereas in optical astronomy, there's always been fierce rivalries between observatories
And you can see it even in the big NSF projects.
You can see it in the panel, the tenure panel cycles.
You can see these kind of fierce rivalries.
You can see it right now in the Jiminy project.

The radio guys mostly have had a tendency to do their debates in private, get their act together, and present a united front, which is how they could build a VLA and a VLBA and other large projects like that.
Another reason I'm mentioning that is I was originally going to be a radio astronomer, and eventually did do some radio astronomy.
But because of my training in graduate school, I didn't have a prejudice against planetary astronomy.
There never was a prejudice against planetary work in radio.

and i wonder if it was because both fields were looked on as pariahs by possessors of large telescopes it may be something in what you say i i think it's also true well let me say i think it's also true that the radio guys are sort of mentally very flexible they were always dealing with strange stuff and so they were willing to entertain new thoughts new ideas and

and somewhat exotic ideas, because they were always dealing with somewhat exotic things by traditional astronomy standards, whereas to do cosmology was a part of a kind of grand intellectual tradition.
And Hubble and on and on like this.
You were dealing with the grandest things.
You had the feeling that Einstein was here and so on.
This was the grandest scale of activity.
Also, the prestige of the big California institutions had a lot to do with this, because they had stressed this kind of program, especially Hubble.
The whole heritage of Hubble and his successors was a powerful intellectual standard that tended towards setting up
the style for what was the best.
I think in a way, while I agree with it all, it's also kind of distorted our view of the universe.
And I have confessed to you that over the years I've changed and broadened my view.
I no longer take cosmology quite as seriously as I used to, although it's still my ultimate basic interest in the universe.
Did you ever get the feeling that you were considered second-rate because you got a degree from UT University of Texas instead of, say, Harvard or Michigan or Caltech?
The year I entered Texas, the number of students doubled.
The next year it doubled again.
I entered in 64.
Harlan had come to Texas in 63.
This was an extraordinary growth rate in the department.
It was change, change, change.
It was instability.
It was a department that had no reputation.
It came out of nothing, very much in the Texas style.
And so...
I certainly was well aware that I was coming from an institution that didn't have name recognition.
However, by the time I graduated eight years later, already the department had a recognition.
For example, one of the graduates during that period in the class that I was in that entered in September of 64 was Beatrice Tinsley.
And Beatrice Tinsley's reputation is as high as it comes.

past tense of course she died so some years ago so she was she was in the same classes that i was in in the fall of 64 and immediately it was apparent her intellectual superiority but another person who was in the class was bob harrington who went to the naval observatory he also just died in january yes very very recently he was in the same class i was in also intellectually very high but that you know there were there were others
who were in the program.
So the program did manage to get good people.
Most of them ultimately got employed.
I must say the Texas program produced a lot of people who stayed in astronomy, who concentrated on getting the job done, and they are all over the world now.
Everywhere I go today, I meet people who were in Texas.
The field is full of astronomy grads.
So in many ways, the degree has more value as every year passes because of that.
Of course, another program that was like that was Arizona.
In the same period of time, Arizona had tremendous growth.
So both of those institutions came up out of nowhere and created new traditions that now are reputable.
How much do you think that NASA money had to do with that in the case of the University of Texas?
It built the 107-inch.
It funded a number of other key people who came to Texas in that era.
But even more than that, I think viewed in a large historic perspective, the whole business of the Sputnik scare, which led to a concentration on science education and science research
there was a vast amount of money spent by the U.S. in the whole infrastructure of scientific research, and it wasn't just NASA money.
It was NSF money and other money sources.
So there was a whole concerted effort to build research and new research groups, new instrumentation of all kinds.
NASA money was a huge part of that.
Incidentally, I spent a summer working on the Apollo program.
I'm very proud that I spent a summer in Houston.
I did a tiny little part of it.
I'm sure my stuff was irrelevant.
I did a Monte Carlo study of the probability that a proton flare would roast the astronauts while they were in flight.
So it was strictly a statistical calculation.
That's what I did for a couple of months.
But I was very proud to have had a small part of Apollo.
Now, that's an example where NASA money
It was employing a lot of people.
I wasn't the only one.
So there were a lot of us who were involved, and it was the whole stimulus of a vast NASA budget pouring into engineering and into scientific research.
But it wasn't just NASA money, and that spirit
degraded somewhat in the 70s.
By the time I graduated, that money flux was out, and there were a number of my fellow students who had trouble finding positions in the 70s.
I did not because I was a technology person, and technology was hot stuff in the 70s.
So I didn't have a job problem, but some of my fellow grad students for a few years did.
Let's see.
Here's an off-the-wall question.
When you meet people on airplanes or something who are not astronomers or scientists, and you tell them what you do, what's their reaction?
Well, standard question number one is, have you heard from them lately, or some question like that.
Well, I mean, do they think that astronomers are parasites, or do they think that we ought to be, that it's a good deal that we have some astronomers in this country, or what?
Some people...
some people simply don't see the point.
And I actually have problems with one of my uncles who apparently has never really understood the justification for science in general, but certainly astronomy.
Are we parasites?
Yes, the answer is yes, of course we are.
My standard statement is that for at least 4,000 years there have been astronomers on government payrolls.
And I feel
That's personally how I feel about it, that I'm a part of a very long-term tradition.
The intellectual and political leadership of the world, of almost every society in the world,
historically, over at least 4,000 years, have all thought that some fraction of their money should go into supporting people like us.
Isn't that, I mean, do you agree with me?
Yes, yes.
I mean, it's a fact.
Good enough for Galileo, it's good enough for me.
It's a historic fact, you know.
So some Babylonian astronomer, he may have been doing what we call astrology today, but that was what passed for professional astronomy in that era.
And intellectually, he was a person not unlike us.
as much like us as he could be in the culture of 4,000 years ago.
I'll give you another example.
I was speaking to Paul Hodge yesterday, who's an AJ editor in the department at University of Washington in Seattle, and he was remarking that he had found in his library copies of volume one of the
of the A.J.
in 1840-something, 1850-something.
And I was speaking about, but your department couldn't have started until somewhat later, 20 years later or something, or couldn't possibly have had this collection.
So he started saying, well, yeah, it's true.
Shortly after the state was formed, a committee of people had to get together to decide what they were going to do with their new society, their culture being created in the wilderness.
And so they would create a university.
What should this university teach?
Well, let's see, it should teach literature and it should teach astronomy.
Astronomy?
Once again, here you see this historic fact that human beings recognize that up there above the sky, above the air, the atmosphere, is something that is of fundamental importance.
and that human culture, society, has to take cognizance of it and that it's appropriate to pay some of us to spend our lives trying to sort it out and interpret it.
So I think that was just one little story, but I think it fits into this grand tradition that we are a part of.
Do you think planetary astronomy is a part of astronomy?
I regard it as such.
It's also a part of geophysics, geology.
That's certainly true, and I'm sure the meteorological people would see affinities to their disciplines as well.
So planetary sits in a crack between the earth sciences and the space sciences.
Certainly the kind of plasma physics that goes on in the solar system has strong analogies and relationships to plasma physics elsewhere in the universe.
Likewise,
We still don't fully understand angular momentum questions in the formations of solar systems, the overall heavy metal flows, where the heavy metals go and where they come from.
Planetary has relationships to all of those.
I think if you take a large-scale view of what our science is all about, planetary science
plays an integral role in it.
However, there is a big distinction being a remote sensing science, which we are.
I feel great affinity to remote sensing people like we're doing EOS and Earth observation systems because we're also a remote sensing science.
The big distinction, though, is they actually get some of the time to get ground truth.
to calibrate their remote sensing effort.
Planetary sciences, because of the planetary missions, get ground truth also.
But the kind of astronomy I've spent most of my life working on never gets ground truth.
And that's a distinction that's pretty clear cut.
Let me ask a question that has to do with planetary astronomy, but all kinds of astronomy.
In the last couple of decades, we've seen a number of subdivisions of the American astronomical site.
It used to just be one American astronomical site.
Now you have historical and high energy and planetary and solar.
And their own journals.
Is that good or bad?
Or just inevitable?
I don't think it's necessarily surprising whether it's a bad thing or not.
I have
trouble deciding.
You actually didn't mention another one that I'm aware of because of my employment in radio astronomy.
Radio astronomers are more interested in going to an ERSE meeting.
Although you'll see plenty of them giving papers here at the AAS meeting.
They are here, but most astronomers, most non-radio astronomers, don't realize that the radio guys have their own
their own environment that's independent of the AAS.
And that's the URSI there, radio science.
Radio scientific international.
Yeah, right, right, right.

Recently, a lot of people, both optical and radio astronomers, have been getting a lot of publicity and, I guess, money from topics such as the search for extraterrestrial intelligence, killer asteroids and comets, looking for other solar systems.
Right.
All in the ozone layer.
Right.
Are they overdoing that?
You mean, are we as a society overdoing it by putting money into those efforts?
No, are astronomers putting too much emphasis on that stuff?
Or is it worth it?
Well, that's the question.
As a society, should we be putting money into those kinds of research?
Is that your question?
Yeah, and should astronomers be doing that?
We're as good as anybody else with our remote sensing attitudes and our technology.
We have the right technology.
And we have the right attitudes.
We're as good scientists to be doing it as anybody else.
And it's not, in that sense, inappropriate.
Now, personally, SETI is this fascinating subject where one isn't quite sure what probabilities to assign to it.
Is it a waste of time is a really tough question because most
Most of us who are trying to pick a research program to work on, we do a calculation of the odds we're going to succeed in finding something interesting.
